item.title: On AI Slop
item.description:
I’ve started to notice a very predictable trend: AI-generated messages in my inbox.

What finally pushed me to write this was how casually people are dumping GPT-generated text into their communications, apparently believing two things:

  • That people won’t notice
  • That people will actually read it

When I received what was clearly an AI-generated Christmas card, that was enough.

What I mean by AI slop

This sits inside a broader problem. AI models are producing large amounts of boring, verbose, low-effort, LAZY content, and it is steadily flooding the web. Others, like Kurzgesagt or Last Week Tonight, have explored this more publicly, but the pattern is easy to recognise once you’ve seen it a few times.

item.title: How we test 100k-Line Nested JSON trees without going insane
item.description:
Today I want to share an interesting challenge that’s been bugging me since I joined InvestSuite last December. It’s stories like this that makes me happy to be a developer, being able to address things that are ruining my day and get rid of them. It feels so satisfying.

We work with massive JSON files (deeply nested, sprawling structures), and we needed a way to test them reliably. The stability of StoryTeller, our personalized report engine, depended on it.

item.title: A Physics book for people who hate Physics
item.description:
My relationship with physics has always been‚Ä¶ troubled.

Probably because I had a high school teacher who never managed to spark any interest in me, I just never caught up. I remember sitting silently at my final exam (Maturit√†) when the physics question came up, completely blank. I also struggled like hell with the physics exam at university. It just never clicked.

And honestly, I don‚Äôt deal with physics in my daily life, so the chance to change that never really came up.

item.title: No, AI is not replacing Data Engineers.
item.description:
Claude 4 landed, and as usual, it kicked off the usual hype cycle. “Best coding model ever” “It writes stories!” “AI is replacing programmers!” And of course, LinkedIn is buzzing with non-technical folks declaring how engineers are doomed and it‚Äôs time to “rethink talent”.

Anthropic CEO even dropped a spicy take: AI could wipe out half of all entry-level white-collar jobs and spike unemployment to 10‚Äì20% in the next 1‚Äì5 years.

item.title: 45 Minutes, 100% AI-Generated Code
item.description:
Last Saturday, I woke up with an idea: what if StoryTeller, the product I work on, had an interactive dashboard with an AI agent that could perform tasks? It was one of those half-formed concepts I could picture it but couldn’t quite articulate it. I knew if I wanted my team to take it seriously, I’d need to build something tangible. Otherwise, it’d just sound like abstract brainstorming.

So, I sinned. I vibe coded.

item.title: Simplicity speaks louder than Complexity
item.description:
A few days ago, I had my first technical presentation at my new company. I joined InvestSuite 3 months ago and it was finally time to present the product I‚Äôm working on, StoryTeller, to a very important customer.

I was nervous.

I‚Äôve given many presentations in the past (to hundreds of people, even at a conference) so this wasn‚Äôt entirely new to me. But I‚Äôm shy by nature, and presenting doesn‚Äôt come easily to me. This time, it felt different because the stakes were higher: it was about selling our product.

item.title: How I created my first Course with Datacamp
item.description:
I just published an online course! covering advanced Microsoft Fabric topics like security, deployment, admin settings, and version control!

Honestly, I never imagined I‚Äôd say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a teacher‚Äù… It feels pretty wild, but here I am!

This project kept me busy for months, and I‚Äôm really proud of how it turned out. Fabric is way more complex than Power BI. It’s a complete data platform with several services, and there‚Äôs not much in-depth content out there for those who want to learn about the technical side. With my experience in a large organization, where I learned about Power BI and Fabric firsthand, I was excited to share what I know.

item.title: Reinventing a Full Stack Web App: here's how
item.description:
üß† Breaking Down Full Stack Development

This post has been sitting in my drafts for over 7 months for two reasons:

First, since the project I created is being considered for production deployment at my company, I need to keep certain details vague.
Second, there’s so much content to cover that finding a starting point was challenging. To make it more digestible, I’m splitting this into at least two parts.

item.title: Data Culture - How we promoted Power BI in a Corporate Environment [üéô Power BI Ticino 2024]
item.description:
Last Friday, I took the stage at the Power BI Ticino Conference to share one of my favorite projects at Acer: our Power BI Champions program. The idea? Find Early Adopters (people who have a curious approach towards new technologies) and put them on the front line to help us promote Power BI and data culture to the rest of the team.

I never imagined I’d speak at a conference when I started this journey… But wow - the positive feedback and amazing people I’ve met make me want to do it again!

item.title: A MUST for Multi-cultural Teams: The Culture Map
item.description:
Cultures can be very different

One of my favorite lessons in my international master’s course was about cultural differences. I remember our instructor showing us funny videos of different cultures interacting. There was an American asking an Indian colleague if they’ll meet next week’s deadline. The response, “I’ll see what I can do” could mean either “sure” or “no way” depending on the cultural context. Needless to add that the American was very confused when the deadline wasn’t met the week after.

item.title: The Pro Trick for Measure Descriptions in Power BI
item.description:
“How does this MEASURE/COLUMN work?”

This is one of the most frequent requests I was receiving. And it’s easy to see why.

In complex Power BI models, users often struggle to understand the meaning of specific measures or columns. This is especially true for ambiguous names like AMSLast12m or columns with deep business logic such as NetAmount. How is it calculated? With VAT? Without it? Help!

Traditionally, there were limited options: ask a colleague, guess the logic, search documentation, or simply try your luck and add it blindly to the report. None of these are ideal solutions, particularly for those new to report creation.

item.title: Personal Notes about Simply Said
item.description:
“Simply Said” is the best communication book I’ve read recently. I discovered it thanks to Jordan Cutler (who runs an amazing tech newsletter) and at first, I considered it a standard communications book. Things like “listen to others,” “be positive,” blah blah.

I was wrong. “Simply Said” is much more than that. That’s why I condensed most of its wisdom into this blog post, and I hope it will inspire you to read it as well.

item.title: Giving our AI superpowers with OpenAI Tools
item.description:
In recent months, I have been experimenting with AI tools to leverage new, powerful technologies and create value. Like you, I am inundated with hype and buzzwords, and this makes things complicate, when trying to get started. While looking for simple answers to my questions, it‚Äôs often challenging to extract real value. So, I want to share my notes to help others with similar needs.

My Business Case: an AI Analyst

Let‚Äôs start with the big question I had in my mind:

item.title: The 3 (+2) ways to Get Data in Power BI, simply explained
item.description:
There’s quite a bit of confusion swirling around about how Power BI reports gather data. Where is the data actually stored? How frequently does it refresh? Depending on the mode you’ve selected, this question can be a bit tricky to tackle.

Let’s simplify things a bit. In this article, I’ll be focusing on Power BI Desktop. Imagine you’ve got a .pbix file on hand and don’t quite have the time to sit through 10-minute technical video from Guy in a Cube that I usually link my users to.

item.title: My AI-tweaked Data Saturdays 23 Notes
item.description:
Last Saturday I had the privilege of attending Data Saturdays #37 at Parma, an event series focused on Microsoft data platform technologies. Covering AI, Database, Business Intelligence, and Cloud, the event promised insights from top experts in Italy (and beyond).

Of course, I wrote down (almost) everything I heard. This blog post is actually a dump of my notes, which I tried to partially automated with a mix of OCR + ChatGPT, which struggled in understanding most of the complex contexts… My disorganized note management didn’t help, poor GPT.

item.title: Finding the Best Time to Go to Work: Now with Car Accidents Data & Power BI Dashboard!
item.description:
I want to express my gratitude for the positive feedbacks I received a few months ago when I used Google Maps data to determine the best times for the daily commute. TL;DR: Mondays are the best, while Wednesdays, and early Fridays are the trickiest times to hit the road.

However, the neatness of this analysis takes a hit when real-world unpredictabilities come into play. Things like heavy traffic, rain, road closures due to accidents, or just that one slow driver in front of you can disrupt even the best-planned routes. So, it’s essential to view these explorations as “what if” games. They provide a general framework but can’t fully account for the chaos of everyday life.

item.title: My Second Brain... 6 Months later: Obsidian update
item.description:
It’s been quite the journey since I first delved into Second Brain technologies for organizing my team’s documentation. I previously shared my initial experiences with Obsidian, and now, it’s time for a comprehensive update. In case you missed my earlier exploration, you can catch up here.

So, what has changed? Let’s dive right in. Since my last update, I’ve continued to utilize Obsidian for secure and structured note organization within my team, enjoying the rapid and intuitive process and enjoying its advantages (flexibility, powerful search system, security, and so on). I’m still in the “honeymoon” phase.

item.title: Analyzing My Commute Data to Find the Best Time to Go to Work
item.description: When my commute buddy and I find ourselves stuck in traffic during our car journeys, we often daydream about finding the ideal route and the optimal time to leave the office in order to avoid these uncomfortable situations. Now, thanks to the power of technology and the inspiration I drew from a fantastic article by @hishamsajid113, I am finally able to back up my theories about the best departure times from home and simulate with real data!

item.title: The unnecessary hype strategy behind Microsoft Fabric
item.description:
If you are into Data Engineering in Microsoft Azure Cloud Environment, you probaly heard about Microsoft Fabric being announced last week at the yearly event Microsoft Build. Well, “heard” is quite an euphesmism: everyone in the field is extremely excited about the announcements of the event. And for good reasons, as it‚Äôs a very big deal for us engineers, working with data every day.

In short, Fabric is a cutting-edge, unified data platform that merges lots of tools together, starting from a common Data Lake where data can be stored (OneLake), and a suite of new tools on top of it that are integrated in the ‚Äúfabric‚Äù of Fabric. Some of them are evolutions of existing systems, like Synapse Data Engineering (Azure Synapse Anaylytics) or Data Factory (Azure Data Factory) for ETL and Data Processing. Others, like my beloved Power BI, have kept the same features but they will be integrated in the platform in the future. Others, like Data Activator(no-code triggers), are brand new.

item.title: How I ended up with AI-generated Music Reviews on TikTok
item.description:
This is a fun story, with a series of technologies and topics that I couldn’t believe they were capable of living together… EDM, TikTok, Text-To-Speech, AI, Playwright… Many times, when going down this over-engineered rabbit hole, I thought, “OK, I have to write about this thing.” And also, “What am I doing here with my time?”

üìö Some context

So, here are a few key things to be aware of:

item.title: What Power BI is still missing
item.description: During these months, I had the chance to take a look at Power BI at the enterprise level, juggling advanced requests from hundreds of users and reports. I am impressed by all the features that the developers have rolled out recently, greatly improving both user and creator experiences. However, one should always maintain an impartial critical vision of the tools, no matter how useful they can be. For this reason, I decided to share my thoughts about some features that are currently lacking or require over-complicated solutions (often from third-party tools), in the hope that Microsoft will find them useful when working on Power BI’s development roadmap.

item.title: Maximizing Productivity with Obsidian: My Second Brain for Organizing Work Notes
item.description:
üß† Introduction to Second Brains & Brain Dumping

As I’m working with data all the time, I’m aware of the importance of keeping it in a safe and structured place, where it can be easily accessed when needed, which could be days, weeks or even years in the future. Thus, organizing my information, tasks, and notes is a key activity in my work (and personal) life. Without a clear system, I would feel lost in chaos, and my productivity would plunge (also considering that my memory sucks).

item.title: Personal Notes about Presentation Patterns
item.description:
Presentation Patterns

Written by Neal Ford, Matthew McCullough and Nathaniel Schutta, “Presentation Patterns - Techniques for Crafting Better Presentations” is an encyclopedia of patterns, tips and common mistakes experienced by the authors, who have delivered thousands of presentations. In particular, they introduce ‚ÄúNo Fluff, Just Stuff‚Äú, a traveling technical conference series covering a wide variety of topics related to software development and management.

During the years, they have build up their toolbox of patterns to provide killer presentations, which are divided in three main sections: Prepare (thinking and setting up the presentation‚Äôs key concepts), Build (creating the slides), Deliver (present the content). While reading, I decided to categorize the items into Patterns, Antipatterns and ‚ÄúOthers‚Äù (type of slides or special kind of presentations which I didn’t consider as a pattern).

item.title: Road to 100% Test Coverage on notion-sdk-py
item.description:
There is something bizarre with me if two of my favourite activities are writing documentation and hitting my head against tests, which are notoriously unexciting activities for many developers üò´

Luckily, we are all unique in our own way and I decided to contribute to the testing module of one of my favorite libraries, notion-sdk-py.

Being a certified Notion user, I use its Web App on a daily basis, and the Python library helps me automatically organize my notes. I even used it for custom bots and documentation. If you don‚Äôt know the tool yet, I recommend trying it out: it may be a bit more complex compared to a classic note editor like Google Keep or Evernote, but its potential is huge.

item.title: A turbulent journey through Power BI source control
item.description:
One of the most annoying issues I have when working with Power BI files is that source control is a real pain. Considering that Microsoft owns Azure, Github, and Power BI, one would hope that they will come up with a solution for comparing two reports without using third-party tools or overly complicated solutions… But that day seems still far in the future.

Here is a story about how I managed to set up a CI/CD pipeline through Azure DevOps Pipeline for providing rudimental version control of our Power BI reports.

item.title: My first weeks at Acer Europe
item.description:
This is a post for my future self when I will be asking myself: ‚ÄúHow were my first days at Acer like?‚Äù.
Note: I’m working at Acer EMEA HQ, so when I mention “Acer”, for simplicity, I mean “Acer Europe”.

üí≠ My expectations

My previous experience was in a small company and a very different sector. Considering this, I was expecting the following challenges in the upcoming scenario:

  • An organization with thousands of employees and decades of history
  • Several departments and key stakeholders to interact with, each one with specific priorities
  • A huge IT department where I’m the youngest member here
  • New technologies to discover: in particular, I’ve never worked with most of the Azure tools we are using
  • A whole new level of complexity

I wasn’t too worried about the previous points, as I’m happy to learn new things and I’m used to managing projects with different stakeholders. Being a Business Intelligence Developer, my tasks were going to be about managing Power BI dashboards and collecting data from databases, more or less what I was used to doing before…

item.title: Personal Notes about The Definitive Guide to DAX
item.description:
Disclaimer: this will be a long, long post, written in my own way. It‚Äôs essentially a dump of my personal notes, taken when reading ‚ÄúThe Definitive Guide to DAX‚Äù written by Alberto Ferrari and Marco Russo. At my new workplace I‚Äôm going to use PowerBI and DAX a lot, thus my boss suggested me to read the book.

Yep, it is big and very technical, with 700+ pages rich in contents, but trust me, that‚Äôs the ‚ÄúBible‚Äù, a must-read for anyone willing to work with PowerBI and DAX. There‚Äôs everything you need, from the basics commands to the most advanced functions, with complex topics such as context transition, query plan, and storage engine. Many examples, in addition, apart from explaining every concept introduced in the book (which focuses a lot on giving clear, practical explanations) explore edge cases that gave me lots of headaches in the past. Further examples and insights can be found on the authors‚Äô site SQLBI.

item.title: My surreal experience with COBOL
item.description: I was feeling curious… So, I decided to challenge myself and try to learn a bit more about COmmon Business-Oriented Language aka COBOL, invented in 1959 by IBM. It‚Äôs not the most popular among programmers, being extremely old and with huge limitations compared to today‚Äôs modern languages… Yet, as we will see, it‚Äôs still alive, hidden in huge legacy codebases in the form of spaghetti code and difficult to get rid of without an entire system redesign.

item.title: First time with Tailwind CSS: showing off my books!
item.description:
I’m back with another post, this time exploring a new CSS framework, Tailwind CSS!

In the previous months I started using Angular and Typescript for some small web apps and dashboards, but I always found CSS management cumbersome. I could spend hours tweaking font-size and align-items parameters and hard-coding variables, and this wasn’t a lot of fun.

That’s why I decided to try Tailwind, which is being heavily recommended by many people in the frontend community! I just needed the right idea before starting to code…

item.title: My Personal Airflow - How I'm monitoring my scripts with Python, Appsmith and SQL Server
item.description:
Here’s the story of how I created my first full-stack project for monitoring my daily activities, using Python and SQL Server in backend and Appsmith for the GUI. I have a lot to learn and process yet, but hey, it’s a start.

üòü The Problem

There are scripts I’m using that are particularly tedious to monitor. The typical structure is the following:

  1. Load data (from a file or manual input)
  2. Send a request to internal DB / very specific API
  3. Compare the data received with the input and if something is wrong, notify me or a colleague.

They must operate locally on specific machines, can’t be containerized, there are severe API limitations in some cases.

item.title: Using a Neural Network for sending memes to my girlfriend
item.description:
Well, my GF’s tastes in memes are simple: she loves wholesome memes and, most importantly, she loves animals.

That’s why I created a fun little project that:

  1. Surfs the subreddit r/wholesomemes using the reddit API
  2. Downloads a few of the hottest memes in the contents folder
  3. Initializes a ResNet50 model that recognizes images containing any animal
  4. Sends them via mail to my GF (positively welcomed)

Final email (3 memes by default)

item.description: Play for the long game. Whatever happens, you will be working for decades. As long as you have joy and happiness in what you do, which is wonderful, do not sweat the daily annoyances. And do not run yourself ragged for a job; what matters is being happy.

item.description: Do not focus on shipping something; you need to create value. The build trap is when organizations become stuck measuring their success by outputs rather than outcomes

item.description: Everything will work out for the best. Or at least, it will happen, so there is no point worrying. I understand that the way to stop time is to stop letting it rule you

item.title: How to Talk So Kids Will Listen & Listen So Kids Will Talk
item.description: Show that you understand them and DESCRIBE what you see and hear. Give information, do not judge, and put yourself in their shoes. Hmm… I see. It must be Annoying/Stressful/Traumatic etc…

item.title: How To Talk To Anyone
item.description: There are unwritten rules in communication, especially in business. Note them all.

item.title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
item.description: Always give others the impression that they are important

item.title: How Your House Works
item.description: Knowing the behind the scenes of appliances is very useful for being able to repair them and not feel intimidated

item.title: Il Fascismo Eterno
item.description: Fascism has some important key traits, let’s not forget them

item.title: Il Genio Non Esiste
item.description: Geniuses are ordinary people, often incredibly lucky or building on others‚Äô work. So, crew, want to become geniuses? Go out there and have fun. And preferably do it legally.

item.title: Impact Mapping: Making a big impact with software products and projects
item.description: Not a priority right now, but an impact map will be a useful tool to manage a project

item.title: Impro
item.description: Be like a child when improvising: pure creativity requires ignoring the mental limits we have been given. In every conversation one person has higher status and one lower

item.title: Influence : the psychology of persuasion
item.description: We do not think with a clear mind. Before making a decision, like buying from a salesperson, ask yourself ‘do I like this choice much more than I expected to?’

item.title: Inspired: How to Create Tech Products Customers Love
item.description: No more roadmaps. The push should come from the bottom, then test. Missionaries, not mercenaries

item.title: It Doesn't Have To Be Crazy at Work
item.description: Real-time sometimes, asynchronous most of the time. If it’s important, slow down.

item.title: It's Ok That You're Not Ok
item.description: Grief cannot be fixed. Only carried forward

item.title: Kitchen Confidential
item.description: The world of professional kitchens is absolutely crazy

item.title: L‚Äôinganno dei confini: Come la geografia governa il mondo
item.description: Borders are the scars of history

item.title: La Rana Bollita, Una Storia di Ansia
item.description: Anxiety can be unbearable and it seems impossible to get out of it. The protagonist made it through with a lot of patience, yoga, exercise, and a desire to change

item.title: La Scienza Delle Pulizie
item.description: Knowing a bit of chemistry can help us navigate this world of fake news and wrong tricks. Acids and bases cancel each other out. And never mix things at random.

item.title: La Scienza Delle Verdure
item.description: The microwave can help a lot. Watch food storage.

item.title: Le Cene Eleganti
item.description: It is a depressing and shameful story; they did not pay enough for it

item.title: Leading Effective Engineering Teams
item.description: A good manager communicates and listens

item.title: Learn Git in a Month of Lunches
item.description: Git is simple in principle: know the basic commands and Google the rest

item.title: Letters from a Stoic
item.description: ‘If you shape your life according to nature, you will never be poor; if according to people’s opinions, you will never be rich.’

item.title: LLM Engineer's Handbook
item.description: Building an AI pipeline can feel like a lot of work, but in the end it is simple

item.title: Looks Good to Me
item.description: You are not your code. A code review is meant to achieve shared code quality for everyone’s benefit

item.title: Love, sex and long-term relationships
item.description: Recognizing AS, communicating with your partner, and helping them understand your differences are key to a stable, lasting relationship

item.title: Man's Search for Meaning
item.description: What you have lived, no power in the world can take from you

item.title: Meditations
item.description: Life is short, don’t worry about what others think

item.title: Meditations for Mortals
item.description: Be imperfect. Let go and understand that you can use your time not to complete everything, but to do something that enriches your life

item.title: Mythos
item.description: The Greeks have many entertaining stories that still resonate today, especially in the etymology of many words

item.title: Never Flinch
item.description: King still writes well

item.title: Never Split The Difference
item.description: Listen (repeat the last 3 words), use calibrated questions with “How” and “What”, show empathy with “It seems that” or “It seems to me that”. Do not be direct; use silence

item.title: No One Would Listen
item.description: Madoff could have been stopped many years earlier, but no one cared to stop the game

item.title: Nonviolent Communication: A Language of Life
item.description: “I feel XXXX when XXXX because XXXX.” Each of us has unmet needs to bring out with empathy

item.title: Nudge
item.description: Well-designed nudges can be very effective in helping people make choices. This is liberal paternalism.

item.title: On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft
item.description: Writing is for being happy, not for money. Start from a very simple concept and build from there. Read a lot

item.title: Packing For Mars
item.description: Organizing space travel, without gravity, is a challenge much, much more complicated than you might expect

item.title: Pale Blue Dot
item.description: Humanity, on this small blue dot, has always been fascinated by what lies beyond. We will never stop being curious

item.title: Presentation Patterns
item.description: Don’t let the presentation tools influence your message; you can have either a document or a presentation

item.title: Principles
item.description: When you experience pain, remember to reflect. You can convert the “pain” of seeing your mistakes and weaknesses into pleasure: you have found an opportunity to get better

item.title: Project Hail Mary
item.description: Knowing the basics of physics, math, and chemistry can save the world

item.title: Python Machine Learning
item.description: Pure gold: a dense read with a lot of formulas and code, but very interesting material with a 360-degree view of ML fundamentals. I feel well prepared now and will revisit it in the future!

item.title: Quiet
item.description: Be yourself. In a world that favors extroverts, there is nothing wrong with understanding that and learning to put yourself out there intentionally. We need to do it.

item.title: Reading Like A Writer
item.description: Read Chekhov. Keep an open mind and be moved by the words that writers have chosen for you

item.title: Reckoning with Risk
item.description: Learn to use “thumb rules” to make simple, fast, and convenient decisions when needed

item.title: Refactoring UI
item.description: Tailwind’s patterns will help you create pleasant designs without overcomplicating things

item.title: Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code
item.description: It is easy to write code that a machine understands. What is hard is writing code that a human understands

item.title: Ruined by Design
item.description: Take responsibility. Bring an ethical conscience to what you build, even indirectly, as a designer.

item.title: Saggio Erotico sulla fine del Mondo
item.description: If we do not do something for the planet we will create irreversible damage and, well… we will die

item.title: Salt Sugar Fat: How the Food Giants Hooked Us
item.description: They may have sugar, salt, and fat on their side, but we have the power to inform ourselves and choose. Also, I did not know there was so much sugar in packaged desserts!

item.title: Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat
item.description: Salt has a bigger impact on flavor than any other element

item.title: Sapiens - A Brief History of Humankind
item.description: Humans are not better than other animals, but with intelligence, specifically communication and the ability to learn, they built an empire. We are still apes that evolved very fast; the brain is the same.

item.title: Say It Like Obama and WIN!
item.description: For a great speech, Obama uses many rhetorical structures, such as repetitions, personifications, analogies

item.title: Simply Said: Communicating Better at Work and Beyond
item.description: Listen. People care only about themselves, so tell them right away why what you are saying matters to them

item.title: Slow Productivity
item.description: Real productivity requires calm and organization, not frantic rushing

item.title: Smart Brevity
item.description: In short, be brief. People do not have time

item.title: Smarter Faster Better
item.description: Productivity is about recognizing choices that other people often overlook. Productivity emerges when people push themselves to think differently!

item.title: So Good They Can't Ignore You
item.description: Don’t follow your passion. You need to offer great value and then specialize and be the best in your niche.

item.title: Spark
item.description: Exercise is important in the long run and for your health, both physical and especially mental

item.title: SQL Antipatterns
item.description: Shooting yourself in the foot with SQL is easy. Think before making certain decisions

item.title: Superhuman Social Skills
item.description: Learn to tell stories, with a calm beginning, a problem/surprise, and a twist. Be a positive change, never a neutral one, in a conversation, or you will never be noticed

item.title: System Design Interview
item.description: Analyze patterns and think carefully to answer system design questions. Start with the simple case then expand

item.title: The $12 Million Stuffed Shark
item.description: Modern art is mostly status and a matter of auction house money

item.title: The 100-Year Life
item.description: Statistically, I will live to 100. My life will be much more variable than I thought, with various work stages. Be flexible about it!

item.title: The 4 Pillars of Investing
item.description: Invest early, a lot, in ETFs/Index Funds with a balanced mix, since you will never know the future.

item.title: The 4-Hour Work Week
item.description: Delegate, 80/20. Your most important resource is time

item.title: The Accounting Game
item.description: On a daily basis, cash runs the business. Not profit

item.title: The Antidote: Happiness for People Who Can't Stand Positive Thinking
item.description: Memento Mori & Stoic Pause

item.title: The Art Of Data Science
item.description: Always think about the right model for your data and do not underestimate bias

item.title: The Art of Seduction
item.description: Everyone has a void; with the right approach, we can fill it

item.title: The Art of SQL
item.description: Performance depends, first and foremost, on a sound database design,and second, on a clear strategy and well-designed programs

item.title: The Best Story Wins
item.description: Knowing how to tell stories, which follow structures unchanged for millennia, is the key to helping people remember ideas

item.title: The Black Hole War
item.description: Information cannot be destroyed, not even by black holes. Or can it? Who knows

item.title: The Black Swan
item.description: You cannot predict major unexpected events, but you will try to explain them after the fact. Do not fall for biases and be wary of Gaussians and models that simplify reality without accounting for black swans

item.title: The Body Keeps The Score
item.description: Past trauma can seriously affect people’s future

item.title: The Book of Awesome
item.description: Life is AWESOME. Enjoy the moments, the small moments of joy that come your way

item.title: The Conversation Code
item.description: Fill up your conversation storage. Explore, have fun, learn, and put into practice what you heard! Most of the time, it’s just scripts.

item.title: The Creativity Code: How AI is Learning to Write, Paint and Think
item.description: Don’t fear AI: behind it are rigorous mathematical rules, whose evolution has been very slow

item.title: The Cuckoo's Egg
item.description: Back then tracking hackers was chaotic, and nobody cared

item.title: The Culture Code
item.description: Build Safety. Share Vulnerability. Establish Purpose

item.title: The Culture Map
item.description: Each culture has behavioral tendencies that can be mapped so you are not surprised by the differences we all have.

item.title: The Defining Decade
item.description: The future isn’t written in the stars. There are no guarantees. So claim your adulthood. Be intentional. Get to work. Pick your family. Do the math. Make your own certainty. Don’t be defined by what you didn’t know or didn’t do. You are deciding your life right now.

item.title: The Definitive Guide to DAX
item.description: Power BI and DAX are complex; you need to know them in detail to use them well

item.title: The Design of Everyday Things
item.description: Good design is invisible; it means everything works. Bad design screams inadequacy and confuses users

item.title: The Dip
item.description: Be the best or step aside. Winners know the perfect time to walk away.

item.title: The E-Myth Revisited
item.description: Running a business is complicated and very hard; you have to manage the Entrepreneur, Manager, and Technician. A nod to franchising: the idea is what gets transmitted to rise above the crowd, not the product itself.

item.title: The Elephant In The Brain
item.description: We humans do and ask for many things because we have hidden motives, often tied to primitive instincts. We are designed that way.

item.title: The Engineering Executive‚Äôs Primer
item.description: Focus on getting the work done, build a solid team, and optimize communication, decision and processes

item.title: The Five Dysfunctions of a Team
item.description: Watch out for absence of trust, fear of conflict, lack of commitment, avoidance of accountability and inattention to results

item.title: The Flavor Bible: The Essential Guide to Culinary Creativity
item.description: Encyclopedia of flavor combinations: you should always create a balanced dish, and you have endless ingredients to play with

item.title: The Food Lab: Better Home Cooking Through Science
item.description: Knowing the science behind reactions in the kitchen will teach you a lot, because you really know what is happening as you cook.

item.title: The Four Agreements
item.description: Don’t take anything personally, don’t make assumptions, always think the best and do your best to awaken

item.title: The Game
item.description: Neg, urgency, 101, isolate… Great, but for serious relationships, you have to be yourself

item.title: The Gervais Principle
item.description: The structure is divided into Losers, Clueless, and Sociopaths, each with its own rules and strategies

item.title: The Great Mental Models
item.description: You can’t really know everything; you can, however, use simpler models that will help you avoid the most common mistakes

item.title: The Intelligent Investor
item.description: Do not trust Mr. Market. Do not buy shares, buy the underlying business: value investing is about noticing whether there is a (wide enough) gap between price and value, and exploiting it.

item.title: The Lean Startup
item.description: Start first, then quickly evolve by gathering feedback from users

item.title: The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat
item.description: There are many strange and particular neurological disorders. We should look at them with a critical eye

item.title: The Manager's Path
item.description: Managers also have their own point of view and needs; it is important to put yourself in their shoes, as they are responsible for guiding you. For a manager: be organized and delegate.

item.title: The Millionaire Fastlane
item.description: Become an entrepreneur, satisfy a (scalable) need, and multiply your wealth exponentially, this is the fastlane

item.title: The Millionaire Next Door
item.description: Income and wealth are two different things: some earn a lot but do not own much, and others earn less but grow their capital through frugality. Many millionaires are of the second type (PAW)

item.title: The Mom Test
item.description: What do we want to learn from these people? Do not share your idea right away; listen to them, or like a kind mom, they will tell you what you want to hear and not the real problems

item.title: The Monk and The Riddle
item.description: A startup needs passion, but also a solid plan and the will to work hard and understand the market

item.title: The Muscle Ladder
item.description: Do not undertrain. Follow a balanced diet. Approach the gym with critical thinking and listen to what science says

item.title: The Music Of Primes
item.description: Mathematics is fascinating. Officially proving the Riemann hypothesis is important but extremely difficult because of how it is structured

item.title: The Obstacle is The Way
item.description: They can throw us in jail, strip us of everything, but we will never be without power: they cannot take away our willpower

item.title: The Personal MBA
item.description: Don’t spend 300k USD on an MBA; get a broad overview of management with this

item.title: The Phoenix Project
item.description: Speed up deploys, collect feedback quickly, use those insights to improve. DevOps foundation: CI/CD! üåü

item.title: The Power of Habit
item.description: Cue -> Routine -> Reward. We are constantly guided by habits, learn to recognize them

item.title: The Productivity Project
item.description: Focus on tasks that have a big impact on your work. Meditate. Reduce caffeine and distractions. Three tasks a day. Limit procrastination

item.title: The Richest Man in Babylon
item.description: Save one-tenth of your earnings and let the children of your saved money have more children, again and again…

item.title: The Scout Mindset
item.description: Let truth win; put it before your ego.

item.title: The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work
item.description:
The key to a happy marriage is how you approach conflict.

In the strongest marriages, husband and wife share a deep sense of meaning. They don’t just ‘get along’ - they also support each other’s hopes and aspirations and build a sense of purpose into their lives together.

item.title: The Shadow of the Wind
item.description: Excellent novel with entertaining characters and constant twists

item.title: The Silent Patient
item.description: Love without honesty does not deserve to be called love

item.title: The Simple Path to Wealth
item.description: Spend less than you earn - invest the surplus- avoid debt

item.title: The Slight Edge
item.description: Small actions compound over time. The things you do every day, the things that don’t look like they matter, do matter. They not only make a difference - they make all the difference.

item.title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck
item.description: A guide to suffering: accept it, and care only about your own battle. Don’t try.

item.title: The Swerve: How the World Became Modern
item.description: Lucretius influenced the entire world with “De Rerum Natura” and the rediscovery of his manuscript was a fascinating adventure

item.title: The Tech Resume Inside Out
item.description: Having a minimal, clear, tidy, and tailored resume is key to finding a job in IT

item.title: The Warren Buffett Way
item.description: Buffett does not buy to speculate; he looks carefully at numbers, managers, and undervalued ideas for the long term

item.title: The Way of the Peaceful Warrior
item.description: There are no ordinary moments! The way of the peaceful warrior is to appreciate every moment, regardless of how dull or ordinary it may seem. Live in the present.

item.title: The Worst Journey in the World
item.description: The South Pole is cold, don’t bring ponies

item.title: The Year of Magical Thinking
item.description: Live with the memories of the people you loved. And know when it is time to move on. Do not get stuck.

item.title: The Zombie Survival Guide
item.description: The only way to kill a zombie is to hit it in the head

item.title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
item.description: It is not possible to explain the rationality (or rather, the lack of it) of the human mind, which relies on two systems that oppose each other depending on the situation

item.title: This Is Vegan Propaganda (And Other Lies the Meat Industry Tells You)
item.description: Being vegan benefits everyone: us, animals, the world.

item.title: Tidy First?: A Personal Exercise in Empirical Software Design
item.description: Tidy First is a state of mind. Always think about how to clean up code.

item.title: Tools of Titans
item.description: The worst thing you can ever do is think that you know enough. Never stop learning. Ever.

item.title: Treasure Islands
item.description: Tax havens give you secrecy and let you shift profits to low-tax jurisdictions.

item.title: Turn the Ship Around
item.description: From leader-follower to leader-leader: progressively give command and responsibility to your subordinates and let them make the decisions they need in the moment

item.title: Uncanny Valley
item.description: The startup world is full of fluff and true believers. Let’s take it with ironic detachment

item.title: We Have No Idea
item.description: We should be EXCITED about all the things we still do not know

item.title: What Color is your Parachute?
item.description: Prepare and understand yourself, study to find the right job for you

item.title: What Every Body is Saying
item.description: Our limbic system, the “honest system”, tells the truth. Watch small details and changes in people carefully, and interpret them in the proper context. We are still animals: in danger, we freeze, flee, fight.

item.title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
item.description: Sleeping enough and regularly is essential to living a happy and healthy life

item.title: Wool
item.description: Don’t trust IT

item.title: World War Z
item.description: If the zombies arrive, run. Aim for the head. Expect it will take years.

item.title: Worth Dying for - The Power and Politics of Flags
item.description: Every flag is much more than a piece of cloth, it represents millions of people and what they believe. There are fascinating stories behind them

item.title: You Can Be Funny and Make People Laugh
item.description: Don’t close yourself off. You can be funny easily by exaggerating and asking imaginative questions, thoughts, and opinions. The important part is to put yourself out there and keep the conversation flowing

item.title: Your Money and Your Brain
item.description: Think Twice. Our brain is full of biases; do not get swept up in the moment. THINK.

item.title: Your Money or Your Life
item.description: Nine Magical Steps to Create a New Road Map

item.title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
item.description: Does Quality permeate the universe? Who knows. Also, if you have patience and attention you can often maintain the bike without always going to a mechanic

item.title: Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future
item.description: Seek the contrarian truth: always ask yourself: “what is a popular belief everyone holds that you disagree with”? How can you use it to your advantage?
